profiles.title: Radiotherapy Course Prescription
profiles.description: A Radiotherapy Course Prescription is a high-level request for a complete course of radiotherapy, which may be fulfilled by one or more phases.

profiles.title: Radiotherapy Course Summary
profiles.description:
A summary of the treatment progress in a radiotherapy course.
Whenever new contributions in the scope of the same course are delivered, this resource is updated (no new resource created).

profiles.title: Radiotherapy Planned Course
profiles.description: A Radiotherapy Planned Course covers all radiotherapy plans to deliver a complete course.

profiles.title: Radiotherapy Adverse Event
profiles.description:
A Radiotherapy Adverse Event is an adverse event resulting from radiation toxicity.   This profile is based on the work of the [Vulcan project](http://www.hl7.org/vulcan/).
Future versions of this IG should reference adverse event profiles from Vulcan, once they are published.  The current profile is inspired by the work of Vulcan and Common Terminology Criteria (CTC) Adverse Event (CTCAE).

profiles.title: Radiotherapy Disease Status
profiles.description: Disease Status Reported by Radiation Oncologist

profiles.title: Radiotherapy Treated Fraction
profiles.description: The treatment of a single fraction of a radiotherapy treatment plan.

profiles.title: Radiotherapy Treatment Session
profiles.description: A radiotherapy treatment session with the patient.

profiles.title: Radiotherapy Phase Prescription
profiles.description:
A Radiotherapy Phase Prescription is a request for one series of fractionated treatments using radiotherapy.
It can define treatment parameters such as modality or technique, and prescribe dose to multiple targets.

profiles.title: Radiotherapy Planned Phase
profiles.description: A Radiotherapy Planned Phase is the summary over all radiotherapy plans to deliver a single phase of radiotherapy treatment.

profiles.title: Radiotherapy Treated Phase
profiles.description: A summary of a phase of radiotherapy treatment that has been delivered. A phase consists of a set of identical fractions. In this context, identical means that each fraction uses the same modality, technique, dose per fraction, and is applied to the same treatment volume or volumes. Because of their spatial relationship or the technique used, all treatment volumes do not necessarily receive the same total dose during a phase.

profiles.title: Radiotherapy Plan Prescription
profiles.description: A Radiotherapy Plan Prescription is a request for radiotherapy treatment with a single treatment plan.

profiles.title: Radiotherapy Treated Plan
profiles.description: A summary of radiotherapy treatment delivered with a single treatment plan.

profiles.title: Radiotherapy Treatment Plan
profiles.description: A Radiotherapy Treatment Plan resource describes the radiotherapy treatment that is planned to be delivered with a single treatment plan.

profiles.title: Radiotherapy Seed Device
profiles.description:
A device that represents implanted seeds for brachytherapy.
The device is specified by the type of radioactive seed (at a minimum).

profiles.title: Radiotherapy Treatment Device
profiles.description: The device used to deliver radiotherapy. For example, a LINAC (external beam) or an afterloader (brachytherapy). The device is specified by at least its manufacturer and model name.

profiles.title: Radiotherapy Volume
profiles.description: A volume of the body used in radiotherapy planning or treatment delivery. This corresponds to the Conceptual Volume in DICOM.

profileElements.Definition: The grade associated with the severity of an adverse event, using CTCAE criteria. The code '0' representing no adverse event may be used to provide positive confirmation that the clinician assessed or considered this particular AE, although the absence of an adverse event is generally not reportable. See https://ctep.cancer.gov/protocolDevelopment/electronic_applications/ctc.htm
Whether the event actually happened, or just had the potential to. Note that this is independent of whether anyone was affected or harmed or how severely.
The MedDRA or NCIT code for the Adverse Event Term. The code should not precoordinate the adverse event grade

The original, verbatim word or phrase as entered by the clinician describing the advese event. The verbatim text may be different than the CTCAE Term given in event.coding.display, since the latter is derived, coded version of the verbatim text. If the AE was selected from a pick list, the event.text must be text displayed in the user interface that was selected by the clinician.
This subject or group impacted by the event.
The Encounter during which AdverseEvent was created or to which the creation of this record is tightly associated.
The date (and perhaps time) when the adverse event occurred.
Describes the type of outcome from the adverse event.
Information on who recorded the adverse event.  May be the patient or a practitioner.
profileElements.Data Type: Reference: Patient, Practitioner, PractitionerRole, or RelatedPerson

profileElements.Definition: Describes the entity that is suspected to have caused the adverse event.
An Extension
Verification of the patient or target position during a treatment fraction.
Method applied to manage respiratory motion.

profileElements.Data Element Name: Extension > Free Breathing Motion Management Technique
profileElements.Definition: Technique to manage respiratory motion with free-breathing. Only allowed if respiratory motion management is free-breathing.
Extension capturing modality and technique of a given radiotherapy procedure.  The allowed combinations of modality and technique are constrained by invariants, one per modality.
profileElements.Data Type: Extension: Radiotherapy Modality And Technique Extension

profileElements.Definition: Extension capturing a modality of external beam or brachytherapy radiation procedures.
Extension capturing a technique of external beam or brachytherapy radiation procedures.
Extension capturing a modality of external beam or brachytherapy radiation procedures.
Extension capturing a technique of external beam or brachytherapy radiation procedures.

The radiation energy used for radiotherapy. The energy spectrum is characterized
by the maximum energy, the maximum accelaration voltage, or the used isotope.
profileElements.Data Type: Quantity, http://hl7.org/fhirpath/System.String, Extension, decimal, code, string, uri, code, or CodeableConcept

profileElements.Definition: Radiotherapy Treatment Applicator Type.
The modality and associated energy used for imaging in Image Guided Radiotherapy (IGRT)
An Extension
An Extension
The purpose of a treatment, medication, or procedure.

profileElements.Data Element Name: Extension > Radiotherapy Dose Prescribed to Volume
profileElements.Definition: Dose parameters prescribed for one radiotherapy volume.

profileElements.Data Element Name: Radiotherapy Dose Prescribed to Volume > Volume
profileElements.Definition: A BodyStructure resource representing the body structure to be treated, for example, Chest Wall Lymph Nodes.

profileElements.Data Element Name: Radiotherapy Dose Prescribed to Volume > Fraction Dose
profileElements.Definition: The dose prescribed per fraction to this volume.

profileElements.Data Element Name: Radiotherapy Dose Prescribed to Volume > Total Dose
profileElements.Definition: The total dose prescribed to this volume within the scope of this ServiceRequest.

profileElements.Data Element Name: Radiotherapy Dose Prescribed to Volume > Fractions
profileElements.Definition: The prescribed number of fractions to deliver the dose. See also extension RadiotherapyFractionsPrescribed which is used instead if fractions are not per volume, e.g. in phases or plans.
A BodyStructure resource representing the body structure to be treated, for example, Chest Wall Lymph Nodes.
Fraction dose is not defined in the Radiotherapy Course Prescription because dose may not be equal in all fractions in which this volume receives dose.
The total dose prescribed to this volume within the scope of this ServiceRequest.
The prescribed number of fractions to deliver the dose. See also extension RadiotherapyFractionsPrescribed which is used instead if fractions are not per volume, e.g. in phases or plans.

Extension providing radiobiologic dose metric using a regular expression:
 BED,
 CGE,
 RBE,
 RBE(factor = \<decimal\>),
 EQD2Gy,
 EQD2Gy(a/b = \<decimal\>).
This flag is true if the radiotherapy course of treatment involves reirradiation of targets or organs at risk that were already irradiated in previous courses.
SHALL have a display name with use = usual and at least one globally unique technical identifier, for example, the Conceptual Volume UID used in DICOM.
Identifiers assigned to this order instance by the orderer and/or the receiver and/or order fulfiller.
Establishes the namespace for the value - that is, a URL that describes a set values that are unique.
The portion of the identifier typically relevant to the user and which is unique within the context of the system.
Identifiers assigned to this order instance by the orderer and/or the receiver and/or order fulfiller.
Establishes the namespace for the value - that is, a URL that describes a set values that are unique.
The portion of the identifier typically relevant to the user and which is unique within the context of the system.
The request takes the place of the referenced completed or terminated request(s).
The status of the order.
Whether the request is a proposal, plan, an original order or a reflex order.
A code that classifies the service for searching, sorting and display purposes (e.g. "Surgical Procedure").
A code that classifies the service for searching, sorting and display purposes (e.g. "Surgical Procedure").
A code that identifies a particular service (i.e., procedure, diagnostic investigation, or panel of investigations) that have been requested.

On whom or what the service is to be performed. This is usually a human patient, but can also be requested on animals, groups of humans or animals, devices such as dialysis machines, or even locations (typically for environmental scans).
The date/time at which the requested service should occur.
When the request transitioned to being actionable.
The individual who initiated the request and has responsibility for its activation.
The desired performer for doing the requested service.  For example, the surgeon, dermatopathologist, endoscopist, etc.
A reference to the the preferred location(s) where the procedure should actually happen. E.g. at home or nursing day care center.
An explanation or justification for why this service is being requested in coded or textual form.   This is often for billing purposes.  May relate to the resources referred to in `supportingInfo`.
Indicates another resource that provides a justification for why this service is being requested.   May relate to the resources referred to in `supportingInfo`.
Anatomic location where the procedure should be performed. This is the target site.
An Extension
The purpose of a treatment, medication, or procedure.

A code explaining the unplanned or premature termination, or normal completion, of a plan of treatment, course of medication, or research study.
This extension is deprecated since it is redundant with the statusReason field.
Extension capturing modality and technique of a given radiotherapy procedure.  The allowed combinations of modality and technique are constrained by invariants, one per modality.
profileElements.Data Type: Extension: Radiotherapy Modality And Technique Extension

profileElements.Definition: Radiotherapy Treatment Applicator Type.
The number of sessions in a course of radiotherapy.
Dose delivered to a given radiotherapy volume.
profileElements.Data Type: Extension: Radiotherapy Dose Delivered To Volume Extension

profileElements.Definition: A BodyStructure resource representing volume in the body where radiation was delivered, for example, Chest Wall Lymph Nodes.

profileElements.Data Element Name: Dose Delivered to Volume > Total Dose Delivered
profileElements.Definition: The total amount of physical radiation delivered to this volume within the scope of this dose delivery, i.e., dose delivered from the Procedure in which this extension is used.

profileElements.Data Element Name: Dose Delivered to Volume > Fractions Delivered
profileElements.Definition: The number of fractions delivered to this volume.
A BodyStructure resource representing volume in the body where radiation was delivered, for example, Chest Wall Lymph Nodes.
The total amount of physical radiation delivered to this volume within the scope of this dose delivery, i.e., dose delivered from the Procedure in which this extension is used.
The number of fractions delivered to this volume.

This flag is true if the dose is determined at a single point.
Point doses are often used to check dose at a specific point in a calculated 3D dose distribution.
Since point doses mostly have a technical role, high-level summaries may decide to exclude them from displays.

This flag is true if the dose is the primary plan dose in a radiotherapy treatment plan.
For a single treatment plan, the primary plan dose serves as the main dose value for tracking delivered dose vs. planned dose.
In summaries over multiple treatment plans, the flag indicates that the dose is a primary plan dose in any of the summarized plans.

Extension providing radiobiologic dose metric using a regular expression:
 BED,
 CGE,
 RBE,
 RBE(factor = \<decimal\>),
 EQD2Gy,
 EQD2Gy(a/b = \<decimal\>).

This flag is true if the fractionation was uniform (i.e., treated with same modality and dose per fraction) and false if the fractionation was mixed. Treatment technique may vary in uniform fractionation.
If the fractionation was uniform, then the correspondence between the physical and biologically effective dose can be determined at the course level.
If the fractionation was not uniform, then the correspondence between the physical and biologically effective dose has to be determined per the phase level.
The flag was introduced to support determination of whether fractionation was uniform when viewing the Radiotherapy Course Summary (without first checking the details of each treatment phase).
This is important in registry use cases to efficiently assess whether checking phase level information is needed.
Method applied to manage respiratory motion.

profileElements.Data Element Name: Extension > Free Breathing Motion Management Technique
profileElements.Definition: Technique to manage respiratory motion with free-breathing. Only allowed if respiratory motion management is free-breathing.
Verification of the patient or target position during a treatment fraction.
The modality and associated energy used for imaging in Image Guided Radiotherapy (IGRT)
An Extension

This flag is true if the radiotherapy course of treatment involves reirradiation of targets or organs at risk that were already irradiated in previous courses.
SHALL have a display name with use = usual and at least one globally unique technical identifier, for example, the Conceptual Volume UID used in DICOM.
Business identifiers assigned to this procedure by the performer or other systems which remain constant as the resource is updated and is propagated from server to server.
Establishes the namespace for the value - that is, a URL that describes a set values that are unique.
The portion of the identifier typically relevant to the user and which is unique within the context of the system.
Business identifiers assigned to this procedure by the performer or other systems which remain constant as the resource is updated and is propagated from server to server.
Establishes the namespace for the value - that is, a URL that describes a set values that are unique.
The portion of the identifier typically relevant to the user and which is unique within the context of the system.
A reference to a resource that contains details of the request for this procedure.
A reference to a resource that contains details of the request for this procedure.
A code specifying the state of the procedure. Generally, this will be the in-progress or completed state.
The specific procedure that is performed. Use text if the exact nature of the procedure cannot be coded (e.g. "Laparoscopic Appendectomy").
The patient on whom the procedure was performed.

Estimated or actual date, date-time, period, or age when the procedure was performed.  Allows a period to support complex procedures that span more than one date, and also allows for the length of the procedure to be captured.
The start of the period. The boundary is inclusive.

The end of the period. If the end of the period is missing, it means no end was known or planned at the time the instance was created. The start may be in the past, and the end date in the future, which means that period is expected/planned to end at that time.
Limited to "real" people rather than equipment.
Limited to "real" people rather than equipment.
The location where the procedure actually happened.  E.g. a newborn at home, a tracheostomy at a restaurant.
The coded reason why the procedure was performed. This may be a coded entity of some type, or may simply be present as text.
The justification of why the procedure was performed.

Coded body structure(s) treated in this course of radiotherapy. These codes represent general locations. For additional detail, refer to the BodyStructures references in the doseDeliveredToVolume extension.
A device that is implanted, removed or otherwise manipulated (calibration, battery replacement, fitting a prosthesis, attaching a wound-vac, etc.) as a focal portion of the Procedure.
Identifies medications, devices and any other substance used as part of the procedure.
Categorization of the kind of evidence contributing to a clinical judgment on cancer disease progression.
The status of the result value.
Describes what was observed. Sometimes this is called the observation "name".
Patient whose disease status is recorded.

The actual focus of an observation when it is not the patient of record representing something or someone associated with the patient such as a spouse, parent, fetus, or donor. For example, fetus observations in a mother's record.  The focus of an observation could also be an existing condition,  an intervention, the subject's diet,  another observation of the subject,  or a body structure such as tumor or implanted device.   An example use case would be using the Observation resource to capture whether the mother is trained to change her child's tracheostomy tube. In this example, the child is the patient of record and the mother is the focus.

The time or time-period the observed value is asserted as being true. For biological subjects - e.g. human patients - this is usually called the "physiologically relevant time". This is usually either the time of the procedure or of specimen collection, but very often the source of the date/time is not known, only the date/time itself.
The information determined as a result of making the observation, if the information has a simple value.
An Extension
Verification of the patient or target position during a treatment fraction.
Method applied to manage respiratory motion.

When the request transitioned to being actionable.

An Extension

The number of planned fractions in this scope.
This extension SHALL only be present if the treatment is structured as countable fractions, for example in a Radiotherapy Planned Phase or in a Radiotherapy Treatment Plan.

profileElements.Data Element Name: Extension > Radiotherapy Dose Planned to Volume
profileElements.Definition: Dose parameters planned for one radiotherapy volume.

profileElements.Data Element Name: Radiotherapy Dose Planned to Volume > Volume
profileElements.Definition: A BodyStructure resource representing the body structure to be treated, for example, Chest Wall Lymph Nodes.

profileElements.Data Element Name: Radiotherapy Dose Planned to Volume > Fraction Dose
profileElements.Definition: The dose planned per fraction to this volume.

profileElements.Data Element Name: Radiotherapy Dose Planned to Volume > Total Dose
profileElements.Definition: The total dose planned to this volume within the scope of this ServiceRequest.

profileElements.Data Element Name: Radiotherapy Dose Planned to Volume > Fractions
profileElements.Definition: The planned number of fractions to deliver the dose. See also extension RadiotherapyFractionsPlanned which is used instead if fractions are the same for all volumes, i.e. in phases or plans.
A BodyStructure resource representing the body structure to be treated, for example, Chest Wall Lymph Nodes.
The dose planned per fraction to this volume.
An Extension

Not used in this profile. In a phase, all volumes are involved in all fractions and the number of fractions is defined in extension radiotherapyFractionsPlanned. To achieve different numbers of fractions for different volumes, multiple phases have to be defined.

This flag is true if the dose is determined at a single point.
Point doses are often used to check dose at a specific point in a calculated 3D dose distribution.
Since point doses mostly have a technical role, high-level summaries may decide to exclude them from displays.

This flag is true if the dose is the primary plan dose in a radiotherapy treatment plan.
For a single treatment plan, the primary plan dose serves as the main dose value for tracking delivered dose vs. planned dose.
In summaries over multiple treatment plans, the flag indicates that the dose is a primary plan dose in any of the summarized plans.

Extension providing radiobiologic dose metric using a regular expression:
 BED,
 CGE,
 RBE,
 RBE(factor = \<decimal\>),
 EQD2Gy,
 EQD2Gy(a/b = \<decimal\>).

Unique device identifier (UDI) assigned to device label or package.  Note that the Device may include multiple udiCarriers as it either may include just the udiCarrier for the jurisdiction it is sold, or for multiple jurisdictions it could have been sold.
The device identifier (DI) is a mandatory, fixed portion of a UDI that identifies the labeler and the specific version or model of a device.
The full UDI carrier as the human readable form (HRF) representation of the barcode string as printed on the packaging of the device.

Estimated or actual date, date-time, period, or age when the procedure was performed.  Allows a period to support complex procedures that span more than one date, and also allows for the length of the procedure to be captured.
The start of the period. The boundary is inclusive.

The end of the period. If the end of the period is missing, it means no end was known or planned at the time the instance was created. The start may be in the past, and the end date in the future, which means that period is expected/planned to end at that time.

The patient or group present at the encounter.
The request this encounter satisfies (e.g. incoming referral or procedure request).
The request this encounter satisfies (e.g. incoming referral or procedure request).
The list of people responsible for providing the service.
Role of participant in encounter.
The period of time that the specified participant participated in the encounter. These can overlap or be sub-sets of the overall encounter's period.
Persons involved in the encounter other than the patient.
The start and end time of the encounter.
Reason the encounter takes place, expressed as a code. For admissions, this can be used for a coded admission diagnosis.
Reason the encounter takes place, expressed as a code. For admissions, this can be used for a coded admission diagnosis.
profileElements.Data Type: Reference: USCoreConditionProblemsHealthConcernsProfile, USCoreConditionEncounterDiagnosisProfile, USCoreProcedureProfile, Observation, or ImmunizationRecommendation

profileElements.Definition: Details about the admission to a healthcare service.
Category or kind of location after discharge.
List of locations where  the patient has been during this encounter.
The location where the encounter takes place.

The organization that is primarily responsible for this Encounter's services. This MAY be the same as the organization on the Patient record, however it could be different, such as if the actor performing the services was from an external organization (which may be billed seperately) for an external consultation.  Refer to the example bundle showing an abbreviated set of Encounters for a colonoscopy.
SHALL have a display name with use = usual and at least one globally unique technical identifier, for example, the Conceptual Volume UID used in DICOM.
Identifier for this instance of the anatomical structure.
The portion of the identifier typically relevant to the user and which is unique within the context of the system.
Unique identifier to reliably identify the same target volume in different requests and procedures, for example, the Conceptual Volume UID used in DICOM.
The portion of the identifier typically relevant to the user and which is unique within the context of the system.
The kind of structure being represented by the body structure at `BodyStructure.location`.  This can define both normal and abnormal morphologies.
The location and locationQualifier codes specify a TG263 body structure comprising the irradiated volume.
Qualifiers that together with the associated location code specify the TG263 body structure comprising the irradiated volume.
A text description of the radiotherapy volume, which SHOULD contain any additional information above and beyond the location and locationQualifier that describe the volume.
The patient for which a radiotherapy procedure is planned or performed.

valueSets.title: Brachytherapy Device Type Value Set
valueSets.description: The type of radioactive seed used in brachytherapy

valueSets.title: Disease Progression Qualifier Value Set
valueSets.description: Qualifier that describes disease progression and/or disease recurrence

valueSets.title: Image Guided Radiotherapy Energy Unit Value Set
valueSets.description:
Unit to characterize the energy spectrum used for imaging in Image Guided Radiotherapy (IGRT).
For photons, the maximum acceleration voltage is given in MV or kV, although those are not units of energy.

valueSets.title: Image Guided Radiotherapy Modality Value Set
valueSets.description: Modality used for imaging in Image Guided Radiotherapy (IGRT)

valueSets.title: Intrafraction Verification Procedure Value Set
valueSets.description: The procedure used for verification of the patient position during a treatment fraction.

valueSets.title: Intrafraction Verification Procedure Qualifier Value Set
valueSets.description: Qualifiers for  procedures used for verification of the patient position during a treatment fraction.

valueSets.title: Adverse Event Severity or Grade Value Set
valueSets.description: CTCAE Grades 0 through 5. The grade of the adverse event, determined by CTCAE criteria, where 0 represents confirmation that the given adverse event did NOT occur, and 5 represents death. Note that grade 0 events are generally not reportable, but may be created to give positive confirmation that the clinician assessed or considered a particular AE.

valueSets.title: Adverse Event Terms Value Set
valueSets.description:
The NCI Common Terminology Criteria for Adverse Events (CTCAE) is utilized for Adverse Event (AE) reporting. The codes are drawn from the NCI Thesaurus. Each CTCAE term is a MedDRA LLT (Lowest Level Term) with corresponding codes that can be used in place of the NCI code. The value set is CTCAE 5.0 and corresponds to MedDRA version 20.1. See https://evs.nci.nih.gov/ftp1/CTCAE/CTCAE_5.0/NCIt_CTCAE_5.0.xlsx.

**Use of 'Other, specify'**: In the event a suitable CTCAE term cannot be found, the appropriate verbatim term SHALL be captured via the 'Other, specify' mechanism. In this case, the verbatim term is populated into the event.text field, the NCIT code for the body system into the event.coding.code field, and the display string corresponding to the code into the event.coding.display field. For example, if reporting the unusual adverse event 'Vulcan-green blood' it will be reported as: event.text of 'Vulcan-green blood', event.coding.display of 'Blood and lymphatic system disorders - Other, specify', and event.coding.code of NCIT code C143323.

valueSets.title: Radiotherapy Category Code Max Value Set
valueSets.description: Category value set required to support backward compatibility by including an inactive SNOMED code

valueSets.title: Radiotherapy Energy Unit Value Set
valueSets.description:
Unit to characterize the energy spectrum used in radiotherapy.
For electrons, the maximum energy is given in MeV.
For photons, the maximum acceleration voltage is given in MV or kV, although those are not units of energy.

valueSets.title: Radiotherapy Free-Breathing Motion Management Technique Value Set

valueSets.title: Radiotherapy Reason for Revision or Adaptation Value Set
valueSets.description: The reason a planned or prescribed radiotherapy treatment was revised, superceded, or adapted.

valueSets.title: Radiotherapy Respiratory Motion Management Value Set
valueSets.description: Method applied to manage respiratory motion.

extensions.title: Reference to DICOM SOP Instance
extensions.description: A reference to a DICOM SOP Instance.

extensions.title: Image Guided Radiotherapy Modality
extensions.description: The modality and associated energy used for imaging in Image Guided Radiotherapy (IGRT)

extensions.title: Intrafraction Verification
extensions.description: Verification of the patient or target position during a treatment fraction.

extensions.title: Radiobiologic Metric
extensions.description:
Extension providing radiobiologic dose metric using a regular expression:
 BED,
 CGE,
 RBE,
 RBE(factor = \<decimal\>),
 EQD2Gy,
 EQD2Gy(a/b = \<decimal\>).

extensions.title: Radiotherapy Adverse Event Grade
extensions.description: The grade associated with the severity of an adverse event, using CTCAE criteria. The code '0' representing no adverse event may be used to provide positive confirmation that the clinician assessed or considered this particular AE, although the absence of an adverse event is generally not reportable. See https://ctep.cancer.gov/protocolDevelopment/electronic_applications/ctc.htm

extensions.title: Course Involves Reirradiation
extensions.description: This flag is true if the radiotherapy course of treatment involves reirradiation of targets or organs at risk that were already irradiated in previous courses.

extensions.title: Radiotherapy Disease Progression Qualifier
extensions.description: Radiotherapy Disease Progression Qualifier

extensions.title: Dose Planned to Volume
extensions.description: Dose parameters planned for one radiotherapy volume.

extensions.title: Dose Prescribed to Volume
extensions.description: Dose parameters prescribed for one radiotherapy volume.

extensions.title: Energy or Isotope
extensions.description:
The radiation energy used for radiotherapy. The energy spectrum is characterized
by the maximum energy, the maximum accelaration voltage, or the used isotope.

extensions.title: Fraction Number in Phase
extensions.description: The number of the fraction in a radiotherapy treatment phase.

extensions.title: Fraction Number in Plan
extensions.description: The number of the fraction in a radiotherapy treatment plan.

extensions.title: Number of Delivered Fractions
extensions.description: The total number of fractions (treatment divisions) actually delivered for this volume.

extensions.title: Number of Planned Fractions
extensions.description:
The number of planned fractions in this scope.
This extension SHALL only be present if the treatment is structured as countable fractions, for example in a Radiotherapy Planned Phase or in a Radiotherapy Treatment Plan.

extensions.title: Number of Prescribed Fractions
extensions.description:
The number of prescribed fractions in this scope.
This extension SHALL only be present if the treatment is structured as countable fractions, for example in a Radiotherapy Phase Prescription.

extensions.title: Free-Breathing Motion Management Technique
extensions.description: Technique to manage respiratory motion with free-breathing.

extensions.title: Point Dose
extensions.description:
This flag is true if the dose is determined at a single point.
Point doses are often used to check dose at a specific point in a calculated 3D dose distribution.
Since point doses mostly have a technical role, high-level summaries may decide to exclude them from displays.

extensions.title: Primary Plan Dose
extensions.description:
This flag is true if the dose is the primary plan dose in a radiotherapy treatment plan.
For a single treatment plan, the primary plan dose serves as the main dose value for tracking delivered dose vs. planned dose.
In summaries over multiple treatment plans, the flag indicates that the dose is a primary plan dose in any of the summarized plans.

extensions.title: Reason for Revision or Adaptation
extensions.description: The reason a planned or prescribed radiotherapy treatment was revised, superceded, or adapted.

extensions.title: Respiratory Motion Management
extensions.description: Method applied to manage respiratory motion.

extensions.title: Session Number
extensions.description: The number of the session a radiotherapy treatment course.

extensions.title: Treatment Applicator Type
extensions.description: Radiotherapy Treatment Applicator Type.

extensions.title: Uniform Fractionation
extensions.description:
This flag is true if the fractionation was uniform (i.e., treated with same modality and dose per fraction) and false if the fractionation was mixed. Treatment technique may vary in uniform fractionation.
If the fractionation was uniform, then the correspondence between the physical and biologically effective dose can be determined at the course level.
If the fractionation was not uniform, then the correspondence between the physical and biologically effective dose has to be determined per the phase level.
The flag was introduced to support determination of whether fractionation was uniform when viewing the Radiotherapy Course Summary (without first checking the details of each treatment phase).
This is important in registry use cases to efficiently assess whether checking phase level information is needed.

extensions.title: Radiotherapy Volume
extensions.description: Extension providing a reference to a RadiotherapyVolume

codeSystems.title: Requested SNOMED Codes Code System
codeSystems.description:
Codes requested from SNOMED by CodeX RT, to be issued at a later date. Where numeric codes are given, these correspond to the expected SNOMED-CT codes.
Terms beginning with 'USCRS-' (for United States Content Request Service) represent requests in April 2023 with no SNOMED code yet approved or assigned.
